tags: andorra blue yellow red animal text vertical
name: Andorra
symbolism:
The design is related to the flags of France, Spain, Catalonia and Foix, the lands historically linked with Andorra.
A flag of three stripes is similar to that of the French Tricolor, while the pattern of a wider middle stripe can be noted on the Spanish flag.
The blue and red of the Andorran flag are also found on the French flag, with red and yellow also being the colors of the Catalan flag (as the old royal symbol of the Crown of Aragon) and the arms of the old County of Foix (currently part of France).
The coat of arms of Andorra in the center of the flag contains historical symbolism to Bishop of Urgell, Count of Foix, Catalonia, and the Viscounty of Béarn.
funfacts:
Although the three vertical stripes may at first appear to be of equal width, the centre yellow stripe is slightly wider than the other two so that the ratio of stripe widths is 8:9:8.
The design is similar to the flags of Romania, Moldova, and Chad but these have stripes of equal width.
The coat of arms makes it one of 28 national flags to contain Christian symbolism.

tags: united arab emirates red green white black horizontal pan-arab
name: United Arab Emirates
symbolism:
Red (Hashemite dynasty): Courage, bravery, hardiness, strength, and unity.
White (Umayyad dynasty): Cleanliness, honesty, peace, and purity.
Green (Fatimid dynasty): Prosperity, hope, joy, love, and optimism.
Black (Abbasid dynasty): Defeating enemies and strength of mind.
funfacts:
Contrary to popular belief; the black part of the flag does not refer to oil.
Abdullah Mohammed Al Maainah was only 19 years old when he designed the flag after a competition was held in the newspaper. He did not know that his design won the competition until the flag was hoisted since the newspaper was printed in black and white.
The design was inspired by a poem, written by 14th century poet Safi al-Din al-Hilli.

tags: afghanistan white black text motto name flag building
name: Afghanistan
symbolism:
White: The purity of faith and government of the Islamic movement of the Taliban.
Text: The Islamic declaration of faith, known as the "shahada".
funfacts: During the 20th century, Afghanistan went through 19 national flags. More than any other country during that time period.

tags: antigua barbuda red black blue white sun triangle
name: Antigua and Barbuda
symbolism:
Black: The African ancestry of the people.
Blue: Hope and the Caribbean Sea.
Red: Energy or life of the people, V is the symbol of victory.
The successive colouring of yellow, blue, and white (from the sun down) also stands for the sun, sea, and sand.
funfacts: A competition to design the flag was held in which more than 600 local people entered. The winning design was put forth by nationally well-known artist and sculptor Sir Reginald Samuel.

tags: anguilla blue red white orange cross british animal
name: Anguilla
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
The coat of arms consists of three dolphins in a circular formation which stand for friendship, wisdom and strength.
The white in the background stands for peace, and the light blue represents the sea, as well as faith, youth, and hope.
funfacts: Since Anguilla is a British overseas territory the flag features the British flag.

tags: albania red black bird animal
name: Albania
symbolism: The red stands for bravery, strength, valour and bloodshed, while the double-headed eagle represents the sovereign state of Albania.
funfacts:
The black double-headed eagle on a red field was Kastrioti's coat of arms and became famous when he led a revolt against the Ottoman Empire resulting in the independence of Albania from 1443 to 1479.
The symbol of the double-headed eagle was re-used by Albanian nationalists during the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries as a symbol of their campaign for their country's independence from the Ottoman Empire.
On 28 November 1912, the Albanian Declaration of Independence was proclaimed in Vlora and the flag, raised by Ismail Qemali, was adopted as the symbol of the new nation.

tags: armenia red blue orange horizontal stripes
name: Armenia
symbolism:
Red: The Armenian Highland, the Armenian people's continued struggle for survival, maintenance of the Christian faith, Armenia's independence and freedom.
Blue: The will of the people of Armenia to live beneath peaceful skies.
Orange: The creative talent and hard-working nature of the people of Armenia.
funfacts: Just over a year before Armenia declared its formal independence from the USSR, the tricolour replaced the 1952 Soviet flag.

tags: angola red black star weapon horizontal stripes
name: Angola
symbolism:
Red: Bloodshed - during Angola's colonial period, independence struggle, and in defense of the country.
Black: Africa.
Gear: Industrial workers and production.
Machete: Peasantry, agricultural production and the armed struggle.
Star: Shaped like the red star, symbolizes international solidarity and progress.
Yellow: The country's wealth.
funfacts:
The Angolan flag is based on the flag of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), which fought Portuguese colonial rule and emerged as the ruling party of Angola following the Angolan Civil War. The MPLA flag is similar to the flag of Angola but features a star in place of the central emblem.
In 2003, a new, more "optimistic" flag was proposed by the Angolan Parliament, but it was not adopted. The design resembled the Costa Rican flag but featured a crude drawing of a sun in the middle which was meant to be reminiscent of cave paintings found in Tchitundo-Hulu cave.

tags: antarctica blue map white
name: Antarctica
symbolism: A plain white map of the continent on a blue background symbolizes neutrality.
funfacts:
Graham Bartram designed the flag using the United Nations as its model.
Antarctica has no official flag as the condominium that governs the continent has not yet formally selected one.
The nations of the Antarctic Treaty use their own national flags at their respective Antarctic research bases. Some nations however have their own flags for their Antarctic possessions.

tags: argentina blue white sun horizontal stripes face
name: Argentina
symbolism:
Popular belief attributes the colors to those of the sky, clouds and the sun; some anthems to the flag like "Aurora" or "Salute to the flag" state so as well.
The emblem is known as the Sun of May (Spanish: Sol de Mayo). Historian Diego Abad de Santillán claimed that the Sun of May was a representation of the Inca sun god Inti.
funfacts:
The Sun of May in the Argentinian flag has 16 straight and 16 waved sunbeams.
It is one of only a few flags to contain a face.

tags: american samoa blue white triangle red bird animal weapon
name: American Samoa
symbolism:
The red, white and blue represent the colors traditionally utilized by both the United States and Samoa.
The bald represents the U.S. and it clutches two Samoan symbols, alluding to America's guardianship over American Samoa, as well as evoking the Great Seal of the United States.
The symbols are a uatogi (a war club, representing the government's power) and a fue (a fly-whisk, representing the wisdom of traditional Samoan leaders).
funfacts:
Before the first Europeans set foot on the islands in the 18th century, Samoa did not use any flags.
Designed by high school student Fareti Sotoa in a competition at the Samoana High School.
A copy of the flag, which was brought to the moon by astronauts on four Apollo missions from 1969-1971, is on display at the Jean P. Haydon Museum in Pago Pago.

tags: austria red white horizontal stripes
name: Austria
symbolism: According to legend, the flag was invented by Duke Leopold V of Austria as a consequence of his fighting during the Siege of Acre. After a fierce battle, his white surcoat was completely drenched in blood. When he removed his belt, the cloth beneath remained unstained, revealing the combination of red-white-red. So taken was he by this singular sight that he adopted the colours and scheme as his banner.
funfacts:
The Austrian triband originated from the arms of the Babenberg dynasty.
The flag is said to have inspired the national flag of Lebanon and the Stars and Bars, ancestor of the present U.S. state flag of Georgia.

tags: australia blue white red cross british star
name: Australia
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
Commonwealth star: Also known as the Federation star, represents the territories of the commonwealth.
Southern Cross: A constellation used to represent Australia since the early days of British settlement. Ivor Evans, one of the flag's designers, intended the Southern Cross to also refer to the four moral virtues ascribed to the four main stars by Dante: justice, prudence, temperance and fortitude.
funfacts:
The number of points on the stars of the Southern Cross on the modern Australian flag differs from the original competition-winning design, in which they ranged between five and nine points each, representing their relative brightness in the night sky.
The stars are named after the first five letters of the Greek alphabet, in decreasing order of brightness in the sky.
In order to simplify manufacture, the British Admiralty standardised the four larger outer stars at seven points each, leaving the smaller, more central star with five points.

tags: aruba blue yellow red white star horizontal stripes whitney_smith
name: Aruba
symbolism:
Blue: The sea that's surrounding the island of Aruba.
Yellow horizontal lines: Abundance of solidarity. They also represent Aruba's economy past and present. Aruba's main past industries consisted of Gold and Aloë Vera and present main income comes from tourism. Yellow also stands for the numerous local flora that blossom yellow flowers.
White: Peace as well as the purity of the hearts of Aruban people who strive for justice, order and liberty.
Red star: The four points of the compass and the different origins of the Aruban population that attracted people from all over the world. It also signifies love and a homage for the indigenous Arubans, that died at Frenchman's pass during a confrontation with the French for the liberty of the island.
funfacts: The flag was designed in part by vexillologist Whitney Smith, who coined the term Vexillology.

tags: åland islands aland blue yellow red cross
name: Åland Islands
symbolism: It is intended to resemble the Swedish flag defaced by a red cross symbolizing Finland.
funfacts:
When Finland obtained independence from Russia in 1917, many Ålanders feared they would lose their Swedish culture and language which led to the native population starting a movement to unite with Sweden. This led to Finland, Sweden, and Russia appealing to the United Nations, who decided in favor of Ålander autonomy.
In 1952, new laws gave Åland the right to make its own flag and a proposed flag resembling the Swedish flag with a blue cross inside was rejected by the president. The final design ended up being the first proposed model.

tags: azerbaijan blue red green moon star horizontal stripes
name: Azerbaijan
symbolism:
Blue: Turkic Multinationalism and the Turkic heritage.
Red: Progress to establish a modern state and the development of democracy.
Green, crescent moon and star: Islam, the religion of majority of Azerbaijanis.
funfacts: While the crescent moon and star are typically seen as markers of Islam, some historians and researchers disagree about why an eight-pointed star is used on the flag of Azerbaijan. Fatali Khan Khoyski points to the eight letters in the word "Azerbaijan" as written in Arabic. The eight points of the star are also thought to stand for the eight Turkic peoples of Azerbaijan. The problem is there are only seven Turkic peoples: Azeris, Ottomans, Jagatais, Tatars, Kipchaks, Selijuks, and Turkomans. It's possible the Kipchaks actually reflect two peoples, the Kazakhs and Kyrgyz, which would make eight.

tags: bosnia and herzegovina blue yellow triangle star
name: Bosnia and Herzegovina
symbolism:
White, blue and yellow: Traditionally associated with Bosnian culture and history.
Triangle: The approximate shape of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the three main ethnic groups of Bosnia and Herzegovina: Bosniaks, Croats, and Serbs.
Blue and stars: Europe, the stars are meant to be infinite in number and thus they continue from top to bottom.
funfacts: Some Bosniaks dislike or have no particular affinity for the flag, preferring the former Bosnian national flag used from 1992 to 1998 (which remains used by some Bosniaks as a sort of ethnic flag), or the former socialist-era Yugoslav flag instead.

tags: barbados blue yellow weapon vertical stripes
name: Barbados
symbolism:
Blue: Ocean surrounding the country and the sky.
Golden middle band: Sand.
Trident three points: The three principles of democracy: government of the people, government for the people, government by the people.
Trident broken lower part: A break from its status as a colony.
funfacts:
The trident symbol was taken from Barbados' colonial badge, where the trident of Poseidon is shown with Britannia holding it.
The design of the flag was created by Grantley W. Prescod and was chosen from an open competition arranged by the Barbados government.

tags: bangladesh green red circle
name: Bangladesh
symbolism:
Red circle: The sun rising over Bengal, and also the blood of those who died for the independence of Bangladesh.
Green: Lushness of the land of Bangladesh and the eternal youth of Bangladeshis.
funfacts:
The red disc is offset slightly toward the hoist so that it appears centred when the flag is flying.
On 16 December 2013, 27,117 people gathered at the National Parade Ground in Dhaka's Sher-e-Bangla Nagar and created a "human flag" which was recorded in Guinness Book of World Records as the world's largest human national flag.

tags: belgium black yellow red vertical stripes
name: Belgium
symbolism:
The colours were taken from the coat of arms of the Duchy of Brabant, a gold lion with red claws and tongue on a black field.
The vertical design is probably based on the flag of France.
funfacts:
In August 1830, the day after the rioting at the Brussels Opera and the start of the Belgian Revolution, the flag of France flew from the city hall of Brussels. The insurgents replaced it with a tricolour of red, yellow, and black horizontal stripes (similar to the one used during the Brabant Revolution of 1789-1790 which had established the United States of Belgium) made at a nearby fabric store. As a result, the Constitution of Belgium describes the colours of the Belgian nation as Red, Yellow, and Black, the reverse order shown in the official flag.
In January 1831, the stripes changed from horizontal to vertical, and in October, the flag attained its modern form, with the black placed at the hoist side of the flag.

tags: burkina faso red green yellow star horizontal stripes pan-african
name: Burkina Faso
symbolism:
Red: The revolution.
Green: The abundance of agricultural and natural riches.
Yellow star: The guiding light of the revolution.
funfacts:
The flag is coloured in the popular Pan-African colours of the Ethiopian flag, reflecting both a break with the country's colonial past and its unity with other African ex-colonies.
The flag was changed when Upper Volta became Burkina Faso on 4 August 1984.

tags: bulgaria white green red horizontal stripes
name: Bulgaria
symbolism:
White: Peace, love, and freedom.
Green: The agricultural wealth of Bulgaria.
Red: The independence struggle and military courage.
funfacts:
The design was derived from the ethnic association of Bulgarians with their Slavic brothers the Russians. The Russian flag was modified by substituting blue for green.
A popular version of the flag, which has no official status, is also commonly known. It has the full coat of arms on the left of the flag, placed across the white and green fields only.

tags: bahrain white red triangle tool
name: Bahrain
symbolism:
The earliest known flags of Bahrain were plain red. In 1820, Bahrain signed a general maritime treaty with the British Empire, and as result, a white stripe was added to the flag to signify the treaty and to distinguish it from the flags commonly used by pirates.
In 1932, a serrated edge was added to the flag in order to differentiate it from those of its neighbours.
The serrated edge was later reduced to five white triangles to symbolize the five pillars of Islam.
funfacts: It is sometimes mistaken for the flag of Qatar, but that flag is maroon, not red, has more points (9) and normally has a much greater length-to-width ratio.

tags: burundi green red white cross star triangle circle diagonal
name: Burundi
symbolism:
White: Peace.
Green: The nation's hopes placed on future development.
Red: The suffering of the nation during its freedom struggle.
Stars: The three major ethnic groups of Burundi: the Hutu, the Twa and the Tutsi. But also for the three elements of the national motto "Unité, Travail, Progrès" (Unity, Work and Progress). They also represent the loyalty that the citizens of the nations have pledged to their God, king and country.
funfacts: When the monarchy ruled over Burundi, a variant flag featuring a karyenda (a drum said to have divine power) was used. It was believed that the drum's messages could be understood only by the mwami (rulers) who made it the laws of the state. Following the abolition of the monarchy in 1966, the karyenda was removed from the flag and replaced with a sorghum plant which is an important agricultural product of the country.

tags: benin green yellow red horizontal stripes pan-african
name: Benin
symbolism:
Green: The hope of a new democracy.
Red: The courage of the ancestors.
Yellow: The treasures of the nation.
funfacts:
On a continental level, the yellow, green and red represent the Pan-African movement.
The colours are the same as the ones utilized in the flag of Ethiopia. This honours the oldest independent country in Africa and the only nation other than Liberia to remain independent during the Scramble for Africa.

tags: saint barthélemy barthelemy white blue red yellow horizontal stripes animal bird crown building text cross fleur-de-lis star ribbon
name: Saint Barthélemy
symbolism:
Pelicans: Representing the local fauna.
Mural crown: Ancient symbol of the Greek gods protecting the cities.
The fleurs-de-lis (France), Maltese cross (Knights Hospitaller), and gold crowns (Sweden) are heraldic reminders of the island's history as a colony.
Eventually, the island returned to French rule and the official flag of Saint Barthélemy became the French tricolor.
funfacts: The text says "Ouanalao" and is the local name of the island.

tags: bermuda red blue white cross british animal boat waves vegetation
name: Bermuda
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
The coat of arms shows a lion holding a shield which bears a picture of a shipwreck on a rock.
The red lion is a symbol of Great Britain and alludes to Bermuda's relationship with that country.
The shipwreck is a depiction of the British Sea Venture, carrying some 150 colonists bound for Virginia, when it was shipwrecked on shoals off Bermuda during a hurricane in 1609.
funfacts:
The flag is unusual for a British overseas territory in that it is used on land in a red ensign form; most other British overseas territories use a version of the blue ensign for general use ashore.
The Latin inscription on the coat of arms reads "Quo Fata Farunt" meaning "Whither the Fates Carry (Us)".

tags: brunei yellow black white red stripes triangle text motto name hand ribbon moon flag diagonal
name: Brunei
symbolism:
Yellow: The sultan of Brunei.
Crescent moon: Islam.
Parasol: Monarchy.
The hands at the side: Benevolence of the government.
The black and white stripes represent Brunei's chief ministers who were once joint-regents and then, after the sultan came of age, senior advisors.
funfacts:
The white stripe is roughly 12% wider than the black one.
On the crescent moon is the national motto of Brunei in Arabic: "Always render service with God's guidance". The ribbon is inscribed with "Brunei, the Abode of Peace".

tags: bolivia red yellow green horizontal stripes
name: Bolivia
symbolism:
Red: Valour of the army.
Yellow: The richness of mineral resources.
Green: The fertility of the land.
funfacts: There may be a connection with the yellow, blue, and red striped flag of “The Liberator,” Simón Bolívar, which formed the basis for the flags of Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela.

tags: bonaire blue white yellow red black triangle stripes star whitney_smith diagonal
name: Bonaire
symbolism:
The blue and yellow triangles represent the sea and sun respectively while the dividing white strip represents the sky.
Red, white, and blue also show Bonaire's loyalty to the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
The black compass represents the population of Bonaire who comes from the four corners of the world.
The red six-pointed star represents the original six villages of Bonaire - Antriol, Nikiboko, Nort Saliña, Playa, Rincon and Tera Korá.
funfacts: The flag was designed in part by vexillologist Whitney Smith, who coined the term Vexillology.

tags: brazil green yellow blue circle text motto star
name: Brazil
symbolism:
The green and yellow are from the previous imperial flag - the green represented the House of Braganza of Pedro I, the first Emperor of Brazil, while the yellow represented the House of Habsburg of his wife, Empress Maria Leopoldina.
The 27 stars represent the Brazilian states and Federal district.
The stars are grouped into constellations like the Southern Cross and the Scorpion and vary in sizes representing the size of the state.
funfacts:
Known in Portuguese as "Verde e amarela" (The Green and Yellow).
The ribbon has the national motto and says "Ordem e Progresso" (Order and Progress).
The star Spica is the only one above of the white band; it symbolises the only part of Brazilian territory in the northern hemisphere (and the State of Pará).
The positions of the stars depicts the sky over the city of Rio de Janeiro on November 15, 1889.

tags: bahamas black blue yellow triangle horizontal stripes
name: Bahamas
symbolism:
Gold: The shining sun, as well as other key land-based natural resources.
Blue: The water surrounding the country.
Black: The strength, vigour and force of the Bahamian people.
Triangle: Their "enterprising and determined" nature to cultivate the abundant natural resources on the land and in the sea.
funfacts:
The design incorporated the elements of various submissions made in a national contest for a new flag prior to independence.
The Bahamian flag is often used as a flag of convenience by foreign-owned merchant vessels because of easy registration and lack of qualification requirements for the crew.

tags: bhutan orange white triangle animal diagonal
name: Bhutan
symbolism:
The dragon ("druk" in Dzongkha, the Bhutanese language) is from Bhutanese mythology.
Yellow: Civil tradition and temporal authority as embodied in the Druk Gyalpo, the Dragon King of Bhutan, whose royal garb traditionally includes a yellow kabney (scarf).
Orange: Buddhist spiritual tradition, particularly the Drukpa Kagyu and Nyingma schools.
Centered dragon: The equal importance of both civic and monastic traditions in the Kingdom of Druk (Bhutan) and evokes the strength of the sacred bond between sovereign and people.
White: Purity of inner thoughts and deeds that unite all the ethnically and linguistically diverse peoples of Bhutan.
Jewels held in Druk's claws: Bhutan's wealth and the security and protection of its people.
funfacts: It was redesigned to match the measurements of the flag of India, which was believed to flutter better.

tags: bouvet island red white blue cross
name: Bouvet Island
symbolism: For symbolism regarding the Norwegian flag, see Norway.
funfacts:
In 1927 a Norwegian expedition erected a small hut, the Norwegian flag was hoisted and the island claimed for Norway.
In 1928 another expedition arrived but by then both the flagpole and hut had been washed away.

tags: botswana blue white black horizontal stripes
name: Botswana
symbolism:
Blue: Water as it is a precious resource in Botswana, which relies on agriculture and suffers from frequent droughts due to the dry and arid climate of the Kalahari Desert.
Black and white band: The harmony and cooperation between the people of different races who live in Botswana, as well as the racial diversity of the country. It also represent the stripes of the zebra, the national animal of Botswana.
funfacts:
Adopted in 1966 to replace the Union Jack, it has been the flag of the Republic of Botswana since the country gained independence that year.
It is one of the few African flags that utilises neither the colours of the Pan-African movement nor the colours of the country's leading political party.

tags: belarus red green white horizontal stripes
name: Belarus
symbolism:
Red: Freedom and the sacrifice of the nation's forefathers.
Green: Life.
The decorative pattern (designed in 1917 by Matrona Markevich) is derived from local plants and flowers. Patterns like it are commonly used in Belarus for woven garments like the traditional ruchnik.
funfacts: Changes made to the Soviet-era flag were the removal of communist symbols (the hammer and sickle and the red star) as well as the reversal of the colours in the ornament pattern.

tags: belize white red white circle weapon tool horizontal stripes text motto ribbon vegetation boat waves human face
name: Belize
symbolism:
The colors on the flag are respectively those of the country's national parties, the People's United Party (PUP), and United Democratic Party (Belize) (UDP).
The 50 leaves recall 1950, the year PUP came to power.
The coat of arms recalls the logging industry that first led to British settlement there. The figures, tools, and mahogany trees represent this industry.
funfacts:
The text says "Sub Umbra Floreo", meaning "Under the Shade I Flourish" and is the national motto.
Belize is the only country to have humans depicted as a major design element on its national flag.
It incorporates 12 different colors and shades, making it the most colorful national flag in the world.

tags: canada red white vertical stripes vegetation
name: Canada
symbolism:
King George V declared the national colours of Canada to be red and white in 1921. Red is symbolic of England and white of France.
The maple leaf has been used as a Canadian emblem since the 18th century.
funfacts: The number of points on the leaf has no special significance; the number and arrangement of the points were chosen after wind tunnel tests showed the current design to be the least blurry of the various designs when tested under high-wind conditions.

tags: cocos islands keeling islands green yellow star moon vegetation circle
name: Cocos (Keeling) Islands
symbolism:
Palm tree: The islands' tropical flora.
Green and yellow: Australia's national colours.
Crescent moon: Islam.
The Southern cross: Australia and the Southern Hemisphere.
funfacts: It was designed by territory resident Mohammed Minkom, who won a design contest as a teenager.

tags: congo blue yellow red triangle star stripes diagonal
name: Democratic Republic of the Congo
symbolism:
Blue: Peace.
Red: The blood of the country's martyrs.
Yellow: The country's wealth.
Star: A radiant future for the country.
funfacts: When the national flag of 1963 was reinstated in 2006, a lighter shade of blue was used.

tags: central africa blue white green yellow red star horizontal stripes pan-african
name: Central African Republic
symbolism:
Blue and white: France.
Green and yellow: Africa.
Red: France and Africa in unity and the respect that Europeans and Africans should have for each other.
Yellow star: Independence.
funfacts: President Jean-Bédel Bokassa considered to replace the flag in 1976 following his conversion to Islam under the influence of Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi.

tags: congo brazzaville green yellow red triangle stripes diagonal pan-african
name: Republic of the Congo
symbolism:
Green: The agriculture and forests of the Congo.
Yellow: The friendship and nobility of the Congolese people.
Red: Unexplained but from a continental viewpoint; the green, yellow and red are the colours of the Pan-African movement.
funfacts: It is the only Pan-African flag to utilize a diagonal pattern in its design.

tags: switzerland red white cross
name: Switzerland
symbolism:
White cross: The Christian cross and the field sign of the Old Swiss Confederacy.
Red: Some historians believe that it symbolised the blood of Christ, while others suggest that the choice was inspired by the colour of the old Bernese flag.
funfacts: It is one of only two square sovereign-state flags, the other being the flag of Vatican City.

tags: côte d'ivoire cote divoire ivory coast orange white green vertical stripes
name: Côte d'Ivoire (Ivory Coast)
symbolism:
Orange: The splendour of national blossoming, while also serving as a reminder of the Northern Savannas.
White: Glorifies peace in purity and union of hearts.
Green: Hope for the future, the luxuriant virgin forest of Ivory Coast, the first great source of national prosperity.
The vertical alignment of the stripes symbolises the dynamic youth which heads for the future under the national motto "Union, Discipline and Work".
funfacts:
When independence from France was declared in 1960, Augustin Loubao proposed changing the orange stripe to red, to symbolize a willingness to shed blood to defend the new republic but the existing flag was retained.
The Irish flag has a similar colour layout to the Ivorian flag, but with the green on the hoist side and a longer proportion (1:2 instead of 2:3). Due to this similarity, in Northern Ireland, Ulster loyalists have sometimes desecrated the Ivorian flag, mistaking it for the Irish one.

tags: cook islands blue white red cross british star circle
name: Cook Islands
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
Stars: The fifteen islands that make up the Cook Islands.
Blue: The ocean and the peaceful nature of the inhabitants.
funfacts: The fifteen islands are Tongareva, Rakahanga, Manihiki, Pukapuka, Nassau, Suwarrow, Palmerston, Aitutaki, Manuae, Takutea, Atiu, Mitiaro, Mauke, Rarotonga and Mangaia.

tags: chile red white blue star horizontal stripes
name: Chile
symbolism:
Blue: The sky and the Pacific Ocean.
White: The snow-covered Andes.
Red: The blood spilled to achieve independence.
The star: May represent a guide to progress and honor while other interpretations says it represents an independent state.
funfacts:
The Chilean flag is also known in Spanish as "La Estrella Solitaria" (The Lone Star). Not to be confused with the flag of the US state of Texas ("The Lone Star State") which adopted its flag 22 years later than Chile.
According to the epic poem La Araucana, the colors were derived from those from the flag flown by the Mapuche during the Arauco War.

tags: cameroon green red yellow vertical stripes star pan-african
name: Cameroon
symbolism:
Centre stripe: Unity; red is the colour of unity, and the star is referred to as "the star of unity".
Yellow: stands for the sun, and also the savannas in the northern part of the country.
Green: The forests in the southern part of Cameroon.
funfacts: Cameroon was the second state to adopt the Pan-African colours.

tags: china red yellow star
name: China
symbolism:
Red: The Chinese Communist Revolution.
Five stars and their relationships to each other: The unity of the Chinese people (the working class, the peasantry, the urban petite bourgeoisie, and the national bourgeoisie) under the leadership of the Communist Party of China (CPC).
funfacts:
Also often known as the Five-starred Red Flag.
The flag was officially unveiled and raised for the first time by Mao Zedong in Beijing's Tiananmen Square on October 1, 1949, at the formal announcement of the establishment of the People's Republic of China.

tags: colombia yellow blue red horizontal stripes
name: Colombia
symbolism:
The flag symbolizes Colombian independence from Spain, gained on July 20, 1810.
Yellow: The riches of the country, the wealth of the Colombian soil, the gold, sovereignty, harmony, justice and agriculture, as well as the Sun, the source of light.
Blue: The sky above, the seas on Colombia's shores, the rivers that run through.
Red: The blood spilled for Colombia's independence and also the effort of Colombian people, their determination and perseverance.
funfacts: The victory of "The Liberator" Simón Bolívar, at the Battle of Boyacá on August 7, 1819, assured the independence of Colombia, and in December of that year Colombia adopted as its national flag the horizontal tricolour of yellow, blue, and red under which Bolívar fought.

tags: costa rica blue white red vegetation star mountain horizontal stripes text name ribbon flag
name: Costa Rica
symbolism:
Blue: The sky, opportunities, idealism, and perseverance.
White: Peace, wisdom and happiness.
Red: The blood spilt by martyrs in defense of the country, as well as the warmth and generosity of the people.
The coat of arms depicts the isthmus between the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea, with 3 volcanoes. The 7 stars stand for the 7 provinces of Costa Rica.
funfacts:
The flag features a stylized version of the flag of itself.
The ribbon of the coat of arms says "Republica de Costa Rica" which is the full name of Costa Rica in Spanish.
The blue, white and red horizontal design was created in 1848 by Pacífica Fernández, wife of then president José María Castro Madriz. Fernández was inspired by France's 1848 Revolution, and the creation of the French Second Republic.

tags: cuba blue white red triangle star horizontal stripes
name: Cuba
symbolism:
The three blue stripes: The three military districts in which Cuba was divided at the time.
White: Purity of the patriot cause, the light.
Red triangle: Originating from the French Revolution and the three ideals of liberty, equality and fraternity: red for the blood and the courage.
Star: Independence.
funfacts:
It is one of the three flags of a currently communist country (the others being Laos and Nepal) that does not use any communist symbolism.
It was the model for the flag of Puerto Rico adopted in 1892 by the Puerto Rican Revolutionary Committee, a pro-independence group that worked under the auspices of the Cuban Revolutionary Party.

tags: cape verde blue white red yellow horizontal stripes star
name: Cape Verde
symbolism:
Blue: The ocean and the sky.
The band of white and red: The road toward the construction of the nation, and its colours stand for peace (white) and effort (red).
The 10 stars: The main islands of the nation.
funfacts: The original flag was nearly identical to the flag of Guinea-Bissau. Their similarity evoked the plans to unite both countries, which were abandoned shortly after independence.

tags: curaçao curacao blue yellow white star horizontal stripes
name: Curaçao
symbolism:
Blue: The sky and sea as well as the loyalty of the people.
Yellow: The bright sun which bathes the island and the happy nature of the people.
The two stars: Curaçao and Klein Curaçao, with the five points on each star symbolise the five continents from which Curaçao's people descend.
funfacts: The design was chosen in a competition that received over 2,000 entries.

tags: christmas island blue green white yellow triangle star animal bird map diagonal
name: Christmas Island
symbolism:
Blue and green: The sea and land respectively.
Stars: The Southern cross constellation refers to the southern hemisphere.
Bird: A golden bosun bird which is a symbol of the island.
Circle with map: A map of the island on a disc representing the mining industry.
funfacts:
The flag was unofficially adopted in 1986 after being chosen the winner in a competition for a flag for the territory. It was designed by Tony Couch of Sydney, Australia who received a price of $100.
The Golden bosun bird is one of six races of the white-tailed tropicbird.

tags: cyprus white orange green vegetation map
name: Cyprus
symbolism:
White: Peace.
A map of the island in copper-orange: The large deposits of copper ore on the island, from which it may have received its name.
Two olive branches: Peace between the island's two communities, Greek and Turkish Cypriots.
funfacts:
According to the constitution, private citizens may fly the flag of Cyprus alongside either the Greek flag, the Turkish flag, or both.
A new flag has been designed by the United Nations in a plan to settle the Cyprus dispute but Greek Cypriots rejected the proposal.

tags: czechia white red blue triangle horizontal stripes pan-slavic
name: Czech Republic
symbolism:
White: The people of the Czech Republic and their peaceful nature and honesty.
Red: Courage, valor and patriotism of the nation.
Blue: Vigilance, truth, loyalty and perseverance.
funfacts:
The Czech Republic flag colors are borrowed from the coat of arms of Bohemia. The blue triangle was added to the Czech flag in 1920 in order to differentiate it from the flag of Poland. It is said that the blue color is representing the State of Moravia.
Upon the dissolution of Czechoslovakia in 1993, the Czech Republic kept the Czechoslovak flag while Slovakia adopted its own flag.

tags: germany black red yellow horizontal stripes
name: Germany
symbolism:
During the Napoleonic Wars (1803-1815), the German struggle against the occupying French forces was significantly symbolised by the colours of black, red, and gold, which became popular after their use in the uniforms of the Lützow Free Corps, a volunteer unit of the Prussian Army. This unit had uniforms in black with red facings and gold buttons. At the time, the colours represented:
Out of the blackness (black) of servitude through bloody (red) battles to the golden (gold) light of freedom.
funfacts:
At the time of the adoption of the flag there were no exact colour specifications other than "Black-Red-Gold", this was fixed in 1999.
When the black-red-gold tricolour was adopted by the Weimar Republic as its flag, it was attacked by conservatives, monarchists, and the far right, who referred to the colours with spiteful nicknames such as Schwarz-Rot-Gelb (black-red-yellow) or even Schwarz-Rot-Senf (black-red-mustard).

tags: djibouti white blue green red triangle horizontal stripes star
name: Djibouti
symbolism:
Blue: The sky and the sea, as well as the Issa Somalis.
Green: The everlasting green of the earth, as well as the Afars (ethnic group inhabiting the Horn of Africa).
White: Peace.
Red star: Unity and the blood shed by the martyrs of independence.
funfacts: The flag is an adaptation of the flag of the Front for the Liberation of the Somali Coast (FLCS), a guerrilla group that led Djibouti with the Ligue Populaire Africaine pour l'Independence (LPAI) to independence.

tags: denmark red white cross
name: Denmark
symbolism:
White: Peace and honesty.
Red: Hardiness, bravery, strength and valour.
The cross is a Nordic cross which represent Christianity.
funfacts:
The flag holds the world record of being the oldest continuously used national flag.
According to legend, the Danish flag fell from heaven on June 15, 1219, during the Battle of Lyndanisse (near modern Tallinn, Estonia) as a sign from God of his support for King Valdemar II against the pagan Estonians.

tags: dominica green yellow black white red purple star circle bird animal horizontal vertical stripes
name: Dominica
symbolism:
Green: The lush vegetation of the island.
The cross: The Trinity and Christianity, with its three colours symbolising the natives, the fertile soil, and the pure water.
The 10 green five-pointed stars stand for the country's 10 parishes.
Red disc: Justice.
The bird is a depiction of the sisserou parrot which is an endangered species with a population of only 250-350 individuals and endemic to the Dominica.
funfacts:
The original flag was designed by playwright Alwin Bully in early 1978 as the country prepared for independence.
The 10 parishes of Dominica are called; St Andrew, St David, St George, St John, St Joseph, St Luke, St Mark, St Patrick, St Paul, and St Peter.
The use of purple makes the flag of Dominica one of only two flags of sovereign states (alongside the flag of Nicaragua) to contain the colour.

tags: dominican republic blue red white weapon cross ribbon cross text motto name flag
name: Dominican Republic
symbolism:
Blue: Liberty.
White: Salvation.
Red: Blood of heroes.
The coat of arms contains Christian symbols in front of the flag of itself.
funfacts:
The coat of arms has a blue ribbon that displays the national motto "Dios, Patria, Libertad" (God, Fatherland, Liberty).
The Dominican revolutionary group known as La Trinitaria, who led the independency movement against Haitian rule, emphasized its Christian heritage by placing a white cross on the background of the previously blue-red flag.

tags: algeria green white red vertical stripes star moon
name: Algeria
symbolism:
Green: Islam.
White: Peace and purity but also a reminder of Emir Abdelkader, who used a white flag in his fight against the French colonial invasion.
Red: Liberty.
The crescent moon and star are also Islamic symbols, but the crescent moon is more closed than those of other Muslim countries because Algerians believe the long crescent moon horns bring happiness.
funfacts: Émilie Busquant (French feminist and anti-colonial activist married to Algerian nationalist leader Messali Hadj) is perhaps best known as the creator of the current Algerian flag. While there is some dispute over who exactly designed green and white with red star and crescent moon symbol, Busquant is generally credited as having sewed the first version of the flag in 1934.

tags: ecuador yellow blue red horizontal stripes weapon mountain boat sun vegetation ribbon animal bird flag
name: Ecuador
symbolism:
Yellow: The crops and the fertile soil.
Blue: The ocean and the clear skies.
Red: Freedom and the blood spilled by the heroes who died in the name of their countrymen's Fatherland.
Coat of arms: The condor on top of the shield stretches his wings to symbolize power, greatness and strength of Ecuador. In the background of the oval shield is the mountain Chimborazo which is the highest mountain in Ecuador. The was built in Guayaquil and was the first seaworthy steamship built in all of South America. The has the features of a Caduceus representing trade and economy. The laurel on the left represents the victories of the republic. The palm leaf on the right side is a symbol of the martyrs of the fight for independence and liberty. The bundle of wood (Fasces) below the shield represents the republican dignity.
funfacts:
The coat of arms contains a depiction of the flag itself.
The flags of Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela are based on a proposal by Venezuelan General Francisco de Miranda, which was adopted by Venezuela in 1811 and later Gran Colombia with some modifications.

tags: estonia blue black white horizontal stripes
name: Estonia
symbolism:
Blue: Endurance and the reflection of the sky in the lakes and the sea.
Black: The earth that feeds the people.
White: An aspiration towards light and purity.
funfacts:
It was officially first adopted as a student organisation flag.
Politician Kaarel Tarand suggested in 2001 that the flag be changed from a tricolour to a Scandinavian-style cross design with the same colours. Advocates for a nordic flag state that Estonians consider themselves a Nordic nation rather than Baltic.

tags: egypt red white black yellow horizontal stripes bird animal text name pan-arab
name: Egypt
symbolism:
Red: The Egyptians' blood in the war against colonization.
White: The purity of the Egyptian's heart.
Black below white: The manner in which darkness is overcome.
The Egyptian eagle of Saladin is centered in the white band. Saladin was a Sunni Kurd and the first sultan of Egypt and Syria and founder of the Ayyubid dynasty.
funfacts:
The development of the modern Egyptian flag was determined first by the Muhammad Ali Dynasty, under whom Egypt was united with Sudan, and later by the rise of Egyptian nationalism and revolutionary ideas among the Egyptian Army.
Egypt's Revolutionary and Liberation flag in 1952 was an inspiration to several Arab countries and was adopted by many Arab states. The same horizontal tricolour is used by Iraq, Syria, Sudan, and Yemen (and formerly Libya), the only difference being the presence (or absence) of distinguishing national emblems in the white band.

tags: western sahara black white green red triangle horizontal stripes moon star pan-arab
name: Western Sahara
symbolism:
Red (Hashemite dynasty): Courage, bravery, hardiness, strength, and unity.
White (Umayyad dynasty): Cleanliness, honesty, peace, and purity.
Green (Fatimid dynasty): Prosperity, hope, joy, love, and optimism.
Black (Abbasid dynasty): Defeating enemies and strength of mind.
The star and crescent moon are considered symbols of Islam, and can be seen on flags of other neighbouring Islamic countries such as Algeria and Mauritania.
funfacts:
Its design is based on that of the Palestinian flag, which in turn was derived from the colors used in the Arab Revolt (referred to as the Pan-Arab colours).
The flag is used in Polisario-controlled areas, while the Moroccan flag is used in the rest of the occupied territory.
It is said to be designed by El Uali Mustapha Sayed, the first president (1976).

tags: eritrea green red blue yellow triangle pan-african
name: Eritrea
symbolism:
Green: The agriculture and livestock of the country.
Blue: The bounty of the sea.
Red: The blood shed in the struggle for Eritrean independence with the 30 leaves in the wreath representing the thirty years spent in the struggle.
funfacts:
The flag combines the basic layout and colours from the flag of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front with an emblem of a wreath with the upright olive branch derived from an earlier flag.
The shape of the red triangle broadly mimics the shape of the country.

tags: spain red yellow horizontal vertical stripes building crown ribbon waves animal vegetation cross fleur-de-lis text motto
name: Spain
symbolism:
The red and gold colours are traditional but have no official symbolic interpretation.
The shield of the coat of arms is divided into quarters, each representing the main kingdoms that eventually merged to form Spain (Castilla, Leon, Aragon and Navarra). At the bottom there's a pomegranate representing the kingdom of Granada.
The center contains fleurs-de-lis representing the House of Borbón (the current royal family).
Around the shield there's a ribbon with the Spanish motto "Plus Ultra" ("Further Beyond" in latin) wrapped around pillars representing Gibraltar.
On top of the shield and the pillars, there are royal crowns representing the Spanish Royal crown and the Imperial crown (Holy Roman empire) respectively.
funfacts: At some point during the 1990s an unofficial version of the Spanish flag sporting an Osborne bull superimposed as some sort of "coat of arms" began appearing in football arenas. This usage has become increasingly popular and this flag is easily seen nowadays during sports events, football or others.

tags: ethiopia green yellow red blue triangle star circle horizontal stripes
name: Ethiopia
symbolism:
Red: The blood spilled in defence of Ethiopia.
Yellow: Peace and harmony between Ethiopia's various ethnic and religious groups.
Green: Hope, or the land and its fertility.
funfacts: Upon gaining independence from colonial rule, several newly established countries in Africa adopted the same three colours in homage to Ethiopia's resistance against foreign occupation. When adopted by Pan-Africanist polities and organisations for their activities, the colours are often referred to as the Pan-African colours.

tags: finland blue white cross
name: Finland
symbolism:
Blue: The country's thousands of lakes and the sky.
White: The snow that covers the land in winter.
Cross: A Nordic cross which represents Christianity.
funfacts:
Like Sweden's, Finland's national flag is based on the Nordic cross. It was adopted after independence from Russia, when many patriotic Finns wanted a special flag for their country, but its design dates back to the 19th century.
The current blue-crossed design was first used in Finland by Nyländska Jaktklubben, a yacht club founded in Helsinki in 1861.
As a special custom in Finland, the flag is flown at Midsummer from 6 pm of Midsummer eve until 9 pm of Midsummer's day. This is done to symbolize the fact that the darkness does not come to any part of Finland during Midsummer's Night.

tags: fiji blue white red cross british bird vegetation animal text ribbon weapon
name: Fiji
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
Blue: The Pacific Ocean, which plays an important part in the lives of the islanders, both in terms of fishing industry and tourism.
Coat of arms: Dividing the shield quarterly is the Cross of St. George which together with the golden lion at the top represents United Kingdom, the former colonial power that ruled over Fiji.
The cacao pod held in the lion's paw, along with the sugarcane, coconut palm and bananas occupying three of the four quadrants, represent the country's natural resources and the dove represents peace.
funfacts:
While some reformists have called for the removal of the Union Flag, seeing it a British colonial emblem, others support its retention for the sake of historical continuity.
The flags of five other independent countries (Australia, Cook Islands, New Zealand, Niue, and Tuvalu) retain the Union Flag in their national flags. But of these, only Fiji is a republic.

tags: falkland islands blue white red cross british waves animal vegetation ribbon star text motto
name: Falkland Islands
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
Coat of arms: The represents the Desire, the vessel in which the English sea-captain John Davis is reputed to have discovered the Falkland Islands in 1592. The motto "Desire the Right", also refers to the ship's name. The ram represents sheep farming, which until recently was the principal economic activity of the islands, and the tussock grass shows the most notable native vegetation.
funfacts: The flag was banned by the Argentine military junta from April to June 1982, during their occupation of the islands, when it was replaced by the flag of Argentina.

tags: micronesia blue white star
name: Micronesia
symbolism:
Blue: The Pacific Ocean.
The four stars: The states in the federation: Chuuk, Pohnpei, Kosrae and Yap.
funfacts: A similar design with six stars was in use from 1965 for the flag of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands. Kosrae was then part of Pohnpei so both were represented by one star. The three extra stars represented Palau, the Marshall Islands and Northern Mariana, which chose not to participate in the Federation.

tags: faroe islands white red blue cross
name: Faroe Islands
symbolism:
Cross: A Nordic cross which represents Christianity.
White: The creators of the flag, the foam of the sea and the pure, radiant sky of the Faroe Islands.
Blue and red: Other Scandinavian and nordic flags; representing the Faroe Islands' bonds with other Nordic countries.
funfacts: On 25 April, 1940, the British occupation government approved the flag for use by Faroese vessels as Britain did not want the same flag as German-occupied Denmark to be used.

tags: france blue white red vertical stripes
name: France
symbolism:
Blue and red are the traditional colours of Paris, used on the city's coat of arms. Blue is identified with Saint Martin, red with Saint Denis.
White: The colour of the king.
The colours may also represent the three main estates of the Ancien Régime (the clergy, the nobility and the bourgeoisie).
funfacts: The tricolour flag is derived from the cockade of France used during the French Revolution, which were circular rosette-like emblems attached to the hats.

tags: gabon green yellow blue horizontal stripes
name: Gabon
symbolism:
Green: The natural resources of Gabon, as well as its extensive forested area that the Gabonese people are economically dependent on in the form of lumber.
Yellow: The sun and also the Equator which cuts across the country.
Blue: The sea, specifically the South Atlantic Ocean along which the country has an extensive coast.
funfacts:
Unlike other former French colonies in Africa, the flag consists of a horizontal tricolour, rather than a vertical one modelled after the flag of France.
The flag does not utilize the green, yellow and red colours of the Pan-African movement, in contrast to its neighbouring countries.

tags: united kingdom great britain red white blue cross british
name: United Kingdom
symbolism:
Red straight cross: The cross of Saint George, patron saint of England.
Red diagonal cross: The Cross of Saint Patrick, patron saint of Ireland.
Blue: The Saltire of Saint Andrew, patron saint of Scotland.
funfacts:
While the flag appears symmetric, the white lines above and below the diagonal red are different widths.
Wales is not represented in the Union Flag by Wales's patron saint (Saint David) but there are suggestions of adding the red Welsh dragon to the center of the flag.
The Police Service of Northern Ireland is the only body in the United Kingdom that is not permitted to fly the Union Flag, and is only permitted to fly its service flag or the Royal Standard in the event of a visit by the Sovereign.

tags: england white red cross
name: England
symbolism: The flag consists of the cross of Saint George, patron saint of England who is often depicted as a crusader.
funfacts:
The association of the red cross as an emblem of England can be traced back to the Late Middle Ages.
The cross was used as a component in the design of the Union Jack in 1606.

tags: northern ireland white red cross star hand crown
name: Northern Ireland
symbolism:
Cross: De Burgh cross with origins in the First Crusade according to legends.
Crown: The monarchy of the United Kingdom.
Red hand: Rooted in Gaelic culture but its meaning is unknown.
Six pointed star: The six counties that make up Northern Ireland.
funfacts:
The only official flag in Northern Ireland is the Union Flag of the United Kingdom.
The flag displayed above is called the Ulster Banner and is used by loyalists and unionists as well as to represent Northern Ireland internationally in some sporting competitions.

tags: scotland blue white triangle cross diagonal
name: Scotland
symbolism:
The flag consists of the cross of Saint Andrew the patron saint of Scotland, an apostle of Jesus.
According to legend, the white cross appeared in the sky above a battle against the Angles.
funfacts: When incorporated as part of the Union Flag during the 17th century, the dark blue applied to Union Flags destined for maritime use was possibly selected on the basis of the durability of darker dyes.

tags: wales white green red animal horizontal stripes
name: Wales
symbolism:
The red dragon has been associated with Wales for centuries, though the origin of the adoption of the dragon symbol is now lost in history and myth.
The green and white stripes were additions by the House of Tudor, the Welsh dynasty that held the English throne from 1485 to 1603.
Green and white are also the colours of the leek, another national emblem of Wales.
funfacts: The oldest known use of the dragon to represent Wales is from the Historia Brittonum, written around 830; the text describes a struggle between two serpents deep underground, which prevents King Vortigern from building a stronghold. This story was later adapted into a prophecy made by the wizard Myrddin (or Merlin) of a long fight between a red dragon and a white dragon. According to the prophecy, the white dragon, representing the Saxons, would at first dominate but eventually the red dragon, symbolising the Britons, would be victorious and recapture Lloegr.

tags: grenada red yellow green triangle vegetation star diagonal
name: Grenada
symbolism:
Green: The islands' vegetation and agriculture.
Yellow: The sun as well as the warmth and wisdom of Grenadians.
Red: Harmony, unity, courage, and vitality.
Stars: The center star represents the capital, St. George's. The six stars on the border represents the country's six administrative divisions.
The symbol of a nutmeg at the side alludes to one of the primary agricultural exports of the islands.
funfacts:
Designed by a local Grenadian, it utilizes the colours of the Pan-African movement.
The country is the second-largest producer of nutmeg in the world, trailing only Indonesia. Consequently, Grenada has acquired the nicknames of "Isle of Spice" and "Spice Island".

tags: georgia white red cross
name: Georgia
symbolism: The large center cross of Saint George and the smaller Bolnisi crosses (officially "bolnur-katskhuri") are symbolic for Christianity, more specifically Jesus and the four evangelists.
funfacts: Originally a banner of the medieval Kingdom of Georgia, it was repopularized in the late 20th and early 21st centuries during the Georgian national revival.

tags: french guiana green yellow red triangle star diagonal
name: French Guiana
symbolism:
Green: The forest.
Yellow: The numerous underground resources.
Red star: The socialist orientation of the country.
funfacts:
The flag was originally the flag of the Guyanese Workers' Union (UTG) and later adopted by the General Council of French Guiana.
The official flag of French Guiana is the flag of France.

tags: guernsey white red yellow cross
name: Guernsey
symbolism:
The red cross of Saint George, patron saint of England.
Gold Norman cross: William the Bastard, Duke of Normandy (who after the conquest became William I of England). William purportedly was given such a cross by Pope Alexander II and flew it on his standard in the Battle of Hastings.
funfacts: Creation of the flag was prompted by confusion at international sporting events over competitors from Guernsey and England using the same flag.

tags: ghana red yellow green black star horizontal stripe pan-african
name: Ghana
symbolism:
Red: The blood of forefathers who led the struggle of independence and shared their blood through death.
Gold: The mineral resources mostly found in the Ashanti region of Ghana, helping to harness the wealth of the country.
Green: The rich forests and natural wealth that provides the nation with oil, food and cash crops, such as cocoa, timber and sheabutter.
The Black star of Africa: The emancipation of Africa and unity against colonialism. Also found in the flags of Guinea-Bissau and São Tomé and Príncipe.
funfacts:
The Ghanaian flag was the second African flag after the flag of the Ethiopian Empire to feature the colours of the Pan-African movement.
The flag's design influenced that of the flag of Guinea-Bissau.
The nickname of the Ghanaian national football team is the "Black Stars".

tags: gibraltar white red horizontal stripes building
name: Gibraltar
symbolism:
White: Peace and honesty.
Red: Hardiness, bravery, strength and valour.
Castle: The fortress of Gibraltar but without resemblance.
Key: The fortress' significance as Gibraltar was seen to be the key to Spain by the Moors and Spanish, and later as the key to the Mediterranean by the British.
funfacts: Gibraltar is the only British Overseas Territory which does not feature the Union Flag in any form although it is widely flown as a stand alone flag within the territory.

tags: greenland red white horizontal stripes circle
name: Greenland
symbolism:
White stripe: The glaciers and ice cap, which cover more than 80% of the island.
Red stripe: The ocean.
Red semicircle: The sun, with its bottom part sunk in the ocean.
White semicircle: The icebergs and pack ice.
funfacts:
The flag of Greenland is the only national flag of a nordic country or territory without a Nordic cross.
In 1985 it was reported that Greenland's flag had exactly the same motif as the flag of a Danish rowing club, which was founded before Greenland's flag was chosen. It is not clear whether this is a case of plagiarism or just a coincidence, but the rowing club gave Greenland permission to use their flag.

tags: gambia red white blue green horizontal stripes pan-african
name: Gambia
symbolism:
Blue: The Gambia River, which is the nation's key feature and is where the country derives its name from.
Red: The sun as well as the savanna.
Green: The forest and the agricultural goods that the Gambian people are heavily dependent on, both for exports and their personal use.
White stripes: Unity and peace.
funfacts:
It was created by Louis Thomasi, who worked as an accountant.
The unofficial flag of planet Mars shares the same colours.

tags: guinea red yellow green vertical stripes africa pan-african
name: Guinea
symbolism:
Red: The blood of the martyrs who died from slavery and wars.
Yellow: The sun and the riches of the country.
Green: The country's vegetation.
funfacts:
The colours were derived from those of the flag of Ghana, following the Pan-African movement.
The flag is the reverse of the flag of Mali.

tags: guadeloupe blue black yellow sun fleur-de-lis horizontal stripes
name: Guadeloupe
symbolism:
The unofficial flag of Guadeloupe is based on the coat of arms of the capital Basse-Terre and has either a black or red background.
Sun: The tropical climate.
Sugar cane: One of Guadeloupe's main crops.
Fleurs-de-lis: The belonging to France.
funfacts: The official flag of Guadeloupe is the flag of France.

tags: equatorial guinea green white red blue triangle star text motto ribbon vegetation horizontal stripes
name: Equatorial Guinea
symbolism:
Green: The natural resources, agriculture and jungles of the country.
Blue: The sea, which connects the main country with the islands.
White: Peace.
Red: The blood shed by the fighters for independence.
Coat of arms: The silk-cotton tree symbolizes the tree that the treaty with Spain was signed under, marking the beginning of the colonial rule. The six stars represent Rio Muni and the offshore islands. The ribbon has the national motto "Unidad, Paz, Justicia" (Unity, Peace, Justice).
funfacts: Under the rule of dictator Francisco Nguema the flag was modified and a different national emblem was used in it (several tools, a sword and a chicken). After he was deposed the original flag was restored.

tags: greece blue white cross horizontal stripes
name: Greece
symbolism:
White and blue: The sky and sea.
Cross: Eastern Orthodox Christianity, the prevailing religion of Greece.
funfacts: According to popular tradition, the nine stripes represent the nine syllables of the phrase "Ελευθερία ή Θάνατος" (Freedom or Death).

tags: south georgia blue white red cross british shield ribbon vegetation animal text motto
name: South Georgia
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
Coat of arms: A golden lion holding a torch, representing the United Kingdom and discovery, together with two stars from the arms of James Cook who discovered the islands. The supporters are an Antarctic fur seal standing on a mountain, and a macaroni penguin standing on ice, both animal native to the islands. The crest is a reindeer, from the two herds of reindeer found on South Georgia Island.
funfacts: The motto on the ribbon reads "Leo Terram Propriam Protegat" which is Latin for "(Let the) Lion protect his own land".

tags: guatemala blue white vertical stripes weapon vegetation bird animal text motto ribbon
name: Guatemala
symbolism:
Blue: Two stripes represent that Guatemala is located between two oceans, the Pacific Ocean and the Atlantic Ocean (Caribbean sea) as well as the sky over the country.
White: Peace and purity.
Coat of arms: The Quetzal is the national bird of Guatemala, and represents freedom and independence of the nation. The crossed Remington rifles are the type used during the 1871 Liberal Revolution, and represent the will to defend Guatemala's interests. The crossed swords represent justice and honor. The laurel wreath represents victory.
funfacts:
The parchment at the center reads "Libertad 15 de septiembre de 1821" (Liberty 15 of September of 1821), the date Guatemala gained independence from Spain.
The blue and white colors, like those of several other countries in the region, are based on the flag of the former Federal Republic of Central America.

tags: guinea-bissau yellow green red black star horizontal stripes pan-african
name: Guinea-Bissau
symbolism:
Black star: The unity of Africa.
Red: The blood shed during the struggle for independence.
Yellow: The sun and mineral wealth.
Green: Hope and forests.
funfacts:
Like the former flag of Cape Verde, the flag is based on that of the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde (PAIGC).
The PAIGC party flag was derived from that of Ghana, which was the first design to use the Pan-African combination of red, yellow, green, and black in 1957.

tags: guam blue red vegetation boat weapon text name
name: Guam
symbolism:
Red border: The blood that it ravaged in World War II and Spanish sovereignty.
Coat of arms: The shape is of the Chamorro sling stones used by the islanders' ancestors as weapons. The coconut tree, growing in infertile sand, symbolizes self-sustenance and determination to grow and survive. The boat is a proa sailing in Agana Bay with the Ritidian Point in the background portraying the people's faithful commitment to passing their proud heritage, culture, and language to the endless sea of future generations.
funfacts:
The flag and emblem was designed by Helen L. Paul, the wife of a U.S. naval officer stationed in Guam.
The emblem says "GUAM" in bright red letters.

tags: guyana green white yellow black red triangle whitney_smith
name: Guyana
symbolism:
Red: Zeal and dynamism.
Gold: Mineral wealth.
Green: Agriculture and forests.
Black: Endurance.
White: Rivers and water.
funfacts: The flag was designed in part by vexillologist Whitney Smith, who coined the term Vexillology.

tags: hong kong red white star vegetation
name: Hong Kong
symbolism:
Red: A festive colour for the Chinese people, used to convey a sense of celebration and nationalism. Also signifies the link re-established between post-colonial Hong Kong and Mainland China.
Red and white: The principle of "one country, two systems".
Flower: The Hong Kong orchid tree flower, a flower discovered in Hong Kong, is meant to serve as a harmonizing symbol.
Stars: The five stars of the Chinese national flag are replicated on the petals of the flower.
funfacts:
The flag of Hong Kong was first officially hoisted on 1 July 1997, during the handover ceremony marking the transfer of sovereignty from Britain back to China.
Architect Tao Ho was in the panel who received design suggestions for the new flag, All six of the final designs were rejected by the PRC and Tao Ho ended up creating the accepted design.

tags: heard island and mcdonald islands blue white red cross british star
name: Heard Island and McDonald Islands
symbolism: For symbolism regarding the Australian flag, see Australia.
funfacts:
Heard Island and McDonald Islands is an uninhabited external territory of Australia in the southern Indian Ocean and is represented by the Australian flag.
Effective government, administration and control of Heard Island and the McDonald Islands was transferred from the United Kingdom to the Australian government in 1947 at the commencement of the first Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition (ANARE) to Heard Island.

tags: honduras blue white horizontal stripes star
name: Honduras
symbolism:
Blue bands: The Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea as well as the blue sky and brotherhood.
White band: The land between the ocean and the sea, the peace and prosperity of its people, and purity of thoughts.
Five stars: The five nations of the former Federal Republic of Central America (El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Honduras, and Guatemala) and the hope that the nations may form a union again.
funfacts: The blue and white colors, like those of several other countries in the region, are based on the flag of the former Federal Republic of Central America.

tags: croatia red white blue horizontal shield star moon stripes animal pan-slavic
name: Croatia
symbolism:
The colours represent the three kingdoms; the Kingdom of Croatia (red and white), the Kingdom of Slavonia (blue and white) and partially the Kingdom of Dalmatia (blue and yellow).
Coat of arms: The chessboard pattern is thought to be of medieval origin but its symbolism is unknown. The smaller shields above is representing the five regions of Croatia; Croatia, Dubrovnik, Dalmatia, Istria and Slavonia.
funfacts: Unlike in many countries, Croatian design more commonly uses symbolism from the coat of arms, rather than from the Croatian flag. Partly because the Pan-Slavic colors are present in many European flags.

tags: haiti blue red white horizontal stripes vegetation weapon hat text motto ribbon flag
name: Haiti
symbolism:
Blue: The black citizens of Haiti.
Red: The people of colour (mulatto).
Coat of arms: A trophy of weapons atop a green hill and a royal palm symbolizing independence. Above the palm tree, there is a Phrygian cap placed as a symbol of freedom.
funfacts:
The ribbon says "L'Union fait la force" (Unity Makes Strength) which is the national motto.
The newly appointed revolutionary leader Jean-Jacques Dessalines created the flag by taking a French tricolor and ripping out the white center, which he discarded. He then asked Catherine Flon, his god-daughter, to sew the remaining bands together.
The flag is one of the few whose design incorporate a depiction of the flag itself.
It was discovered at the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin that Haiti and Liechtenstein were using the same flag. This led to the addition of a crown to the design of the flag of Liechtenstein.

tags: hungary red white green horizontal stripes
name: Hungary
symbolism:
Red: Strength and the blood spilled for the fatherland.
White: Faithfulness and freedom.
Green: Hope and the pastures of Hungary.
funfacts:
The modern flag of Hungary originated from the national freedom movement from before 1848 and features a tricolour element, which is based upon the French flag, as a reflection of the ideas of the French revolution.
The stripes are horizontal rather than vertical to prevent confusion with the Italian flag despite the banner in that form predating the Italian tricolour by at least 7 years.

tags: indonesia red white horizontal stripes
name: Indonesia
symbolism:
Red: Courage and the human body or physical life.
White: Purity and the soul or spiritual life.
funfacts:
The origin of red and white can be traced back to the older common Austronesian mythology of the duality of Mother Earth (red) and Father Sky (white).
After Indonesia's independence was recognized, Monaco (which have a nearly identical flag) filed a complaint which was largely ignored.
Red and white textile colouring was available in ancient Indonesia. White is the natural colour of woven cotton fabrics, while red is one of the earliest natural dyes, acquired either from teak leaves, the flowers of Averrhoa bilimbi, or the skin of mangosteen fruits.

tags: ireland green white orange vertical stripes
name: Ireland
symbolism:
Green: Roman Catholics.
Orange: The minority Protestants who were supporters of William of Orange.
White: A lasting peace and hope for union between Protestants and Catholics in Ireland.
funfacts:
The oldest known reference to the use of the three colours of green, white and orange as a nationalist emblem dates from September 1830 when tricolour cockades were worn at a meeting held to celebrate the French Revolution of that year.
The Ivorian flag has a similar colour layout to the flag of the Irish flag, but with the orange on the hoist side and a shorter proportion (2:3 instead of 1:2). Due to this similarity, in Northern Ireland, Ulster loyalists have sometimes desecrated the Ivorian flag, mistaking it for the Irish one.

tags: israel white blue triangle horizontal stripes star
name: Israel
symbolism:
Blue: God's glory, purity and severity.
White: Divine benevolence.
Star: The Star of David, a generally recognized symbol of modern Jewish identity and Judaism.
The basic design recalls the Tallit, the Jewish prayer shawl, which is white with black or blue stripes.
funfacts:
The flag was designed for the Zionist Movement in 1891.
The Star of David was not considered an exclusively Jewish symbol until after it began to be used on the gravestones of fallen Jewish soldiers in World War I.
Palestinians including Yasser Arafat and Hamas have claimed that the two blue stripes on the Israeli flag represent the Nile and Euphrates rivers and allege that Israel desires to eventually seize all the land in between.

tags: isle of man red white yellow star
name: Isle of Man
symbolism:
The three legs is called a triskelion but its symbolism and origin is unknown.
According to Norse mythology, the triskelion was a symbol of the movement of the sun through the heavens.
funfacts: The usage of a triskelion was very popular with Scandinavian cultures, and the symbol may have been introduced to the Isle by the Norse descendants of King Amlaíb Cuarán, who ruled the island between the 10th century and 1266.

tags: india orange white green blue horizontal stripes circle
name: India
symbolism:
Orange (saffron): Courage and sacrifice.
White: Peace and truth.
Green: Faith and chivalry.
Wheel: The Ashoka Chakra representing the eternal wheel of law as well as movement and change.
funfacts: By law, the flag is to be made of khadi, a special type of hand-spun cloth or silk, made popular by Mahatma Gandhi.

tags: british indian ocean territory blue red white cross crown waves vegetation
name: British Indian Ocean Territory
symbolism:
For symbolism regarding the Union Jack, see United Kingdom.
Waves: The Indian Ocean, where the islands are located.
Palm tree and St Edward's Crown are symbols of the Indian Ocean Territory.
funfacts: Given that it is impossible for civilians to visit the British Indian Ocean Territory, it is not clear how widely this flag is used.

tags: iraq red white black green horizontal stripes text motto pan-arab
name: Iraq
symbolism:
Red (Hashemite dynasty): Courage, bravery, hardiness, strength, and unity.
White (Umayyad dynasty): Cleanliness, honesty, peace, and purity.
Green (Fatimid dynasty): Prosperity, hope, joy, love, and optimism.
Black (Abbasid dynasty): Defeating enemies and strength of mind.
funfacts:
The text is the takbīr, the phrase "Allahu akbar" meaning "God is the greatest" in Arabic.
The colors are those used in the Arab Revolt and referred to as the Pan-Arab colours.

tags: iran green white red text motto horizontal stripes
name: Iran
symbolism:
Green: Growth, happiness, unity, nature, vitality and the Iranian languages.
White: Freedom.
Red: Bravery, fire, life, love, warmth, and sophistication.
Emblem: Geometrically symmetric form of the word "Allah", meaning "God" in Arabic.
funfacts: The takbir, the phrase "Allahu akbar" meaning "God is the greatest" in Arabic, is written 11 times in Kufic script.

tags: iceland blue red white cross
name: Iceland
symbolism:
Cross: A Nordic cross which represents Christianity.
Red: The fire produced by the island's volcanoes.
White: The ice and snow that covers Iceland
Blue: The mountains of the island.
funfacts: According to a legend described in Andrew Evans' Iceland, a red cloth with a white cross fell from the heavens, ensuring Danish victory at the Battle of Valdemar in the 13th century. Denmark then used the cross on its flag throughout its nordic territories as a sign of divine right. Upon Iceland's independence, they continued to use the Christian symbol.

tags: italy green white red vertical stripes
name: Italy
symbolism:
Green: Natural rights; social equality and freedom. Alternatively the meadows and the Mediterranean maquis.
White: The snow of the Alps.
Red: The blood spilt in the Wars of Italian Independence and Unification.
funfacts:
The Italian tricolour, like other tricolour flags, is inspired by the French one, introduced by the revolution in the autumn of 1790 on French Navy warships, and symbol of the renewal perpetrated by the origins of Jacobinism.
The Italian gazettes at the time of the French revolution had created confusion about the replacement of green with blue and red, reporting the news that the French tricolour was green, white and red. When the correct information on the French tricolour arrived in Italy, the Italian Jacobins decided to keep green instead of blue.

tags: jersey white red triangle cross animal crown diagonal
name: Jersey
symbolism:
Red cross: The Cross of Saint Patrick, patron saint of Ireland.
Crown: Attributed to the house of Plantagenet and indicates the islands loyalty to that dynasty.
Lions: Derived from the seal granted to the island's bailiff by Edward I in 1279.
funfacts: The flag was used to signal the neutrality of the Channel Islands during wars between England and France.

tags: jamaica green yellow black triangle cross diagonal
name: Jamaica
symbolism:
Black: The strength and creativity of the people which has allowed them to overcome difficulties.
Yellow: The wealth of the country and the golden sunshine.
Green: The lush vegetation of the island, as well as hope.
funfacts: The only national flag that does not contain a shade of the colors red, white, or blue.

tags: jordan black white green red triangle horizontal stripes star pan-arab
name: Jordan
symbolism:
Red (Hashemite dynasty): Courage, bravery, hardiness, strength, and unity.
White (Umayyad dynasty): Cleanliness, honesty, peace, and purity.
Green (Fatimid dynasty): Prosperity, hope, joy, love, and optimism.
Black (Abbasid dynasty): Defeating enemies and strength of mind.
The star: The unity of the Arab people. Its seven-pointed star refers to the seven verses of Al-Fatiha and possibly also the faith in one God, humanity, humility, national spirit, virtue, social justice, and aspiration.
funfacts: The colors are those used in the Arab Revolt and referred to as the Pan-Arab colours.

tags: japan white red circle sun
name: Japan
symbolism: Since ancient times, the sun has been a symbol of national unity because of the close relationship between national rule and the sun.
funfacts:
The flag is commonly known in Japan as "Hinomaru" (日の丸, the "circle of the sun").
The sun is closely related to the Imperial family, as legend states the imperial throne was descended from the sun goddess Amaterasu.

tags: kenya black white red green weapon shield horizontal stripes pan-african
name: Kenya
symbolism:
Black: The people of the Republic of Kenya.
Red: The blood shed during the fight for independence.
Green: The country's landscape and natural wealth.
White: Peace and honesty.
Maasai shield and spears: The defense of things mentioned above.
funfacts: The flag is based on that of Kenya African National Union and the colors of the Pan-African movement.

tags: kyrgyzstan red yellow sun circle building
name: Kyrgyzstan
symbolism:
Red: Bravery and valor and alludes to the emblem hoisted by Manas, the national hero of Kyrgyzstan.
Sun: Peace and prosperity, while its 40 rays stand for the number of tribes united by Manas to fight against the Mongols.
Center: The opening in the center of the roof of a yurt (traditional tent) which symbolizes the origin of life, the unity of time and space, as well as the people's hearth and home.
funfacts:
The center of the flag is a depiction of the first thing one sees when waking up in a yurt, namely the construction of the pinnacle of every Kyrgyz yurt with three crisscrossing laths across the circular opening at the top of the yurt.
